projects.name: English Language Programs
projects.tagline: a marketing website powered by WordPress

description.background: This site provides details about exchange opportunities for US-based English as a Second Language teachers funded by the U.S. Department of State.
description.details: It was refreshed with a new WordPress theme in 2022, with an atypical file structure (Roots by Bedrock). It features an interactive map powered by MapBox and an AJAX Story post search component. These and other interactive elements are powered by Vue JS.
description.reflection: Though the theme was initially being designed and developed by an outside agency just as I began in the role, I took it over before launch, completing the buildout with interactivity and accessibility improvements.

projects.name: Community of Practice
projects.tagline: a private online community powered by WordPress

description.background: This community is exclusively for alumni of English Language Programs, exchange opportunities for US-based English as a Second Language teachers funded by the U.S. Department of State.
description.details: The theme is highly customized with numerous custom post types, taxonomies, and tricky integrations. The most consequential plugin is LearnDash LMS, which allows the organization to host courses inside of the community. This plugin provides limited customization out of the box, however, which requires significant ongoing development work to ensure that it provides a look and feel similar to the rest of the community. The site integrates with Auth0 so users can use the same credentials on two of the organization's web platforms.
description.reflection: WordPress would not have been my platform of choice for an online community. When I inherited this legacy project, non admin users were expected to navigate not only a custom frontend, but also periodically the WordPress admin panel to create and edit posts and manage their comments. One of the more major changes I implemented were frontend views to prevent community members from ever needing to see the admin panel. Now, most newer members likely have no idea that the community is powered by WordPress.

projects.name: Simple Alt Text Generator Plugin
projects.tagline: a WordPress plugin to fill in missing image alt text with descriptions provided by OpenAI's ChatGPT 5 Nano

description.background: In my role as IT Projects Developer at Georgetown University, I conduct accessibility reviews and apply code improvements twice a year. Each time I analyze our site with accessibility checkers (e.g. SiteImprove), I find an ever larger number of images that are missing alt text, which leaves users with visual impairments or slow connections unable to receive any benefit from these images. Since others on our team who are not as familiar with web accessibiliy update the content of the site, this issue has been challenging for me to address.
description.details: I decided to create a plugin rather than adding custom functionality to our organization's WordPress sites as I expect this is a widespread issue. The plugin searches the site's Media Library for images without alt text and then allows the user to have alt text generated by Open AI's ChatGPT 5 Nano using their own OpenAI API key. This allows me to make the plugin itself free to install with the costs negotiated between the user and Open AI. The actual communication between the WordPress installation and Open AI is handled by a microservice I created using Vercel's AI SDK.
description.reflection: This was my first attempt to make a WordPress plugin, which helped me better understand WordPress admin panel features and tooling such as the Settings API. Though similar plugins already exist on the WordPress marketplace, I found that they obscured they had opaque cost structures. One of the biggest issues with AI models at the moment is their variable pricing. The largest services charge based upon usage tokens with no industry standard. This makes it hard for a user, let alone a AI-powered service to determine a fair subscription price. Providing this type of plugin for free works as an experiemental or educational project, but it is not a sustainable way to support the developer community in finding practical applications of AI.

projects.name: Alt Text Generator Microservice
projects.tagline: a service that helps fill in missing image alt text with descriptions provided by OpenAI's ChatGPT 5 Nano

description.background: In my role as IT Projects Developer at Georgetown University, I conduct accessibility reviews and apply code improvements twice a year. Each time I analyze our site with accessibility checkers (e.g. SiteImprove), I find an ever larger number of images that are missing alt text, which leaves users with visual impairments or slow connections unable to receive any benefit from these images. Since others on our team who are not as familiar with web accessibiliy update the content of the site, this issue has been challenging for me to address.
description.details: Rather than working with Open AI's API directly within the WordPress backend I decided to use Vercel's AI SDK in a separate server environment for several reasons. First, I wanted to allow for the possibility of creating interfaces for other platforms with the same underlying features. Also, Vercel's AI SDK allows you to use many different models from different providers with the same API. Since generative AI is rapidly evolving, I would like to be able to more quickly adapt to new models or services that could provide descriptions of images more accurately or efficiently.
description.reflection: Though this was my first time working with the AI SDK, I had a workable prototype of the service up and running within less than an hour. It almost took more time to set up an Open AI API account than to create this functionality. Vercel has done their part in trying to make AI models available to developers, but it remains to be seen how many beneficial and affordable use cases there may be.

projects.name: Writing Toolkit
projects.tagline: a suite of digital English writing tools

description.background: Composition is often taught explicitly with learners actually completing writing steps independently.  This project embeds common advice in college composition classes implicitly, supporting learners as they write.
description.details: Writing Toolkit is a web application designed to be mobile-first and performant around the globe.  English language learners are the primary target user, which requires the use of a global CDN and a stateless architecture as users are based around the world.  The application helps users manage writing as individual projects, with a variety of support strategies (style feedback, grammar checking, plagiarism detection, etc.) depending on the project template.
description.reflection: The application is the most complete integration of my experiences as an English language instructor and my web development skillset.

description.background: For English language learners in particular, the breadth of vocabulary expected in creative writing can be daunting. It is difficult to avoid overusing familiar words.
description.details: Robomuse is a light user interface to access word association features from Datamuse, an AI-based service that offers English language word suggestions. Suggestions supported by Robomuse include rhyming words, adjectives, nouns, and single-word substitutions for phrases.
description.reflection: While limited in terms of scope, the application can be used by native and non-native English language writers on a variety of device form factors.

projects.name: IELTS Practice
projects.tagline: helps students prepare for the IELTS exam

description.background: The IELTS is an international English language exam widely used to assess a candidate's ability to use English in a business or academic environment. On the exam's speaking section, examinees are asked to prepare and deliver a short impromptu speech with specific time constraints.
description.details: This mobile-first app combines several basic functionalities necessary for test preparation. First, the app provides a random prompt modeled after sample questions provided by the IELTS website. The app also integrates timer functionality in the form of a dynamically generated window border.
description.reflection: When preparing for an exam, students often overlook time constraints, which are often the cause of text anxiety. By integrating this functionality, this solution is more effective than simply reviewing example test questions.

projects.name: Seatsmart
projects.tagline: adds transparency to classroom participation feedback

description.background:
Seatsmart offers a convenient way to implement classroom participation guidance by the Department of English at Fort Hays State University for courses conducted at campuses in China. 
At its core, Seatsmart is a simple implementation of instructor classroom management practices that are considered effective for courses conducted at FHSU satellite campuses in China. Paper-based seating charts with spaces for annotation have been in use for some time and are still the preferred choice for many faculty members. Seatsmart offers a digital alternative as a convenience, while striving to add features that are difficult to implement in analog (e.g. trend calculations, randomization, etc.). The choice of colors and typography is meant to fit the university context (adult learners).
description.details:
Internet connection stability is a serious concern for faculty. In addition, the application deals with student records related to participation, which should be stored securely. Seatsmart is designed to be offline-first, with all data stored on the user's machine. This storage is transparently located in the default OS documents folder, which is separate from application files. This allows the user to update (replace) the application without impacting partication records. 
When Internet access is available, instructors can use the Remote feature to access basic features from a mobile device. They can also engage with students in Activities for realtime formative assessments. Data is encrypted during transport and this information is not stored in any cloud database. This is powered by a realtime server on the backend. 
Every attempt is made to ensure design and UX consistency for PC and Mac, the operating systems currently used by faculty. However, desktop (larger) screen sizes are given less priority as faculty are provided or rely upon laptop computers. An additional effort has been made to support OSX-specific APIs such as the touchbar, recognizing that faculty members who have chosen to purchase their own computers have sometimes selected more advanced Apple computers with this feature.
description.reflection: As a standalone application, Seatsmart currently includes all planned functionality.  However, due to the public health crisis in China in 2020, face-to-face instruction has been interrupted, which puts this project on hold.

projects.name: TOEIC Photo
projects.tagline: helps students prepare for the TOEIC exam

description.background: The TOEIC is an international English language exam widely used to assess a candidate's ability to use English in a business environment. On the exam's speaking section, examinees are asked to describe a random photo, demonstrating their range and depth of vocabulary.
description.details: This mobile-first app combines several basic functionalities necessary for test preparation. First, the app provides a random photo with subjects modeled after example provided by the ETS website. The app also integrates timer functionality. Further, the app includes a gamified version of the activity with a process similar to the parlor game Taboo.
description.reflection: When preparing for an exam, students often overlook time constraints, which are often the cause of text anxiety. By integrating this functionality, this solution is more effective than simply reviewing example photos from the test website.

projects.name: Seatsmart Remote
projects.tagline: extends features of the Seatsmart app to mobile devices

description.background: This web-based remote UI communicates in realtime with the desktop application Seatsmart powered by Seatsmart Remote Server.
description.details: When Internet access is available, instructors can use the Remote feature to access basic features from a mobile device. Data is encrypted during transport and this information is not stored in any cloud database.
description.reflection: This application demonstrates how progressive enhancements can serve the needs of many users without risking wider accessibility. While Seatsmart Remote will never replace the original desktop application, it has introduced interactions that have influenced other features, such as Seatsmart Activities.

projects.name: Gist
projects.tagline: gamifies avoiding plagiarism when writing summaries

description.background: This game was created with English language learners in mind, who often struggle to use language flexibly and understand standards of academic integrity in Anglophone academia.
description.details: Gist is a text-based game that challenges a player to summarize a short text while avoiding common issues: plagiarism, reliance on close synonyms, and wordiness. As a serious game intended for older learners, Gist focuses on providing formative feedback to learners to encourage reflection and iteration. If successful, the game might help learners build an implicit understanding of academic integrity and best practices regarding paraphrasing.
description.reflection: This project was my first serious attempt to apply basic computional linguistics strategies in order to analyze natural text input. Large portions of the server functions that support Gist have been reused in other projects. Therefore, the project was a true stepping stone to more complex applications.

description.background: This realtime server powers remote functionality within the desktop application Seatsmart.
description.details: When Internet access is available, instructors can use the Remote feature to access basic features from a mobile device. Students can also connect on their mobile devices for realtime activities. Data is encrypted during transport and this information is not stored in any cloud database.
description.reflection: Seatsmart was originally planned as an offline application due to the perceived instability of Internet services in (mainland) China. After a tentative trial of realtime features using this server, the application quickly proved its reliability. After introducing remote functionality, colleagues began suggesting other realtime features to make their classroom more interactive. Since existing realtime services are blocked in China, Seatsmart has grown to fill in the gaps.

projects.name: Seatsmart Activities
projects.tagline: adds realtime formative assessment activities to Seatsmart

description.background: Existing popular realtime education services are blocked in China. This mobile-first web app allows students to connect with each other and their instructor on their personal devices.
description.details: When Internet access is available, instructors can launch realtime formative assessment activities with their students. Data is encrypted during transport and this information is not stored in any cloud database.
description.reflection: Since colleagues teach groups as large as 120 students, it can be difficult to foster meaningful interactions in the classroom. Simple activities such as surveys or resource sharing can be nearly impossible to do in analog, especially when anonymity is important. Instructors use Seatsmart Activities to make their class sessions more engaging and to gather feedback from students.

projects.name: BEC Vantage Practice
projects.tagline: helps students prepare for an English language exam

description.background: The BEC Vantage is an international English language exam widely used to assess a candidate's ability to use English in a business environment. On the exam's speaking section, examinees are asked to collaborate with a stranger to discuss solutions to a common business problem.
description.details: This mobile-first app combines several basic functionalities necessary for test preparation. First, the app provides a random collaboration prompt modeled after sample questions provided by Cambridge English. The app also integrates timer functionality in the form of a dynamically generated window border. Two or three students can work together around the same device.
description.reflection: When preparing for an exam, students often overlook time constraints, which are often the cause of text anxiety. By integrating this functionality, this solution is more effective than simply reviewing example test questions.

projects.name: Chronology
projects.tagline: a timeline creator to support language acquisition

description.background: Many Indo-European languages include the concept of verb tenses to mark time. Acquiring these verb forms requires a much longer period of exposure to the language. This application helps a language learner understand chronologies as communicated in the target language.
description.details: This application was created in the context of an Interaction Design course at the University of Missouri. It features a minimalistic interface to reduce distraction so that the users can continue to focus on what they hear. It was created in plain JavaScript in a MVC (OOP) pattern.
description.reflection: Though it made sense to me at the time, the interface relies too heavily on ambiguous icons to communicate meaning. Though users would be able to negotiate for clearer understanding in the moment, the use of higher-fidelity graphics (photos) would likely provide a better experience.

projects.name: Mixtape
projects.tagline: a mixtape creation interface for Apple Music

description.background: Modern music players like Apple Music allow you to create playlists, but it can be difficult to share them with others.
description.details: This application uses the mixtape concept to add meta details to a playlist built from the Apple Music library. I challenged myself to limit the project to a frontend interface without any backend data storage. Instead, all details related to the mixtape are stored in query parameters. This delivers the fundamental functionality users expect without requiring registration.
description.reflection: I enjoy playing and listening to music in my daily life, so this project is a labor of love. It is challenging to rely so much on a single external API, however. In fact, I decided to use a beta version of MusicKit JS as version 1 was unstable. The long term viability of this application entirely depends on Apple's vision.
